Cleaning, Merging, and Exploring Qualitative Data

Source: vignettes/Intro_to_DedooseR.Rmd
Intro_to_DedooseR.Rmd

Qualitative projects rarely begin with a dataset that is ready for analysis and raw Dedoose exports do not include a dedicated ID column. Instead, they arrive with transcript metadata, coder names, ranges, weights, and one column per code. This vignette walks through a typical workflow—cleaning excerpts, merging related codes, and reviewing the underlying text—using three core functions: clean_data(), merge_codes(), and view_excerpts(). The mock tibble above mirrors that structure so the entire vignette can render without private files.

library(DedooseR)
library(tibble)

# Mock excerpts that mimic a Dedoose export ----------------------------------
demo_excerpts <- tribble(
  ~`Media Title`, ~`Excerpt Range`, ~`Excerpt Creator`, ~`Excerpt Date`,
  ~`Excerpt Copy`, ~`Resource Creator`, ~`Resource Date`,
  ~`Codes Applied Combined`,
  ~`Code: Sense of Belonging & Connectedness Applied`,
  ~`Code: Sense of Belonging & Connectedness Range`,
  ~`Code: Sense of Belonging & Connectedness Weight`,
  ~`Code: Sense of Belonging & Connectedness\\Peers Applied`,
  ~`Code: Sense of Belonging & Connectedness\\Peers Range`,
  ~`Code: Sense of Belonging & Connectedness\\Peers Weight`,
  ~`Code: Long-term Impact Applied`,
  ~`Code: Long-term Impact Range`,
  ~`Code: Long-term Impact Weight`,
  "Interview: Program Launch", "Excerpt 12-56", "Aliyah", as.Date("2023-04-12"),
    "I finally felt like I belonged with my friends and in my school.",
    "Staff Team", as.Date("2023-04-01"),
    "Sense of Belonging & Connectedness",
    "True", "1-2", 1,
    "True", "1-1", 1,
    "False", NA_character_, NA_real_,
  "Focus Group: Summer Session", "Excerpt 04-38", "Rohan", as.Date("2023-07-28"),
    "Staff kept checking in, so staying engaged over summer felt easier.",
    "Evaluation Lead", as.Date("2023-07-15"),
    "Sense of Belonging & Connectedness; Long-term Impact",
    "False", NA_character_, NA_real_,
    "True", "2-3", 2,
    "True", "2-2", 2,
  "Interview: Alumni Reflections", "Excerpt 77-112", "Aliyah", as.Date("2024-01-08"),
    "That mentorship still shapes the goals I set for myself.",
    "Alumni Coordinator", as.Date("2023-12-20"),
    "Long-term Impact",
    "False", NA_character_, NA_real_,
    "False", NA_character_, NA_real_,
    "True", "4-5", 3
)

demo_excerpts
#> # A tibble: 3 × 17
#>   `Media Title`  `Excerpt Range` `Excerpt Creator` `Excerpt Date` `Excerpt Copy`
#>   <chr>          <chr>           <chr>             <date>         <chr>         
#> 1 Interview: Pr… Excerpt 12-56   Aliyah            2023-04-12     I finally fel…
#> 2 Focus Group: … Excerpt 04-38   Rohan             2023-07-28     Staff kept ch…
#> 3 Interview: Al… Excerpt 77-112  Aliyah            2024-01-08     That mentorsh…
#> # ℹ 12 more variables: `Resource Creator` <chr>, `Resource Date` <date>,
#> #   `Codes Applied Combined` <chr>,
#> #   `Code: Sense of Belonging & Connectedness Applied` <chr>,
#> #   `Code: Sense of Belonging & Connectedness Range` <chr>,
#> #   `Code: Sense of Belonging & Connectedness Weight` <dbl>,
#> #   `Code: Sense of Belonging & Connectedness\\Peers Applied` <chr>,
#> #   `Code: Sense of Belonging & Connectedness\\Peers Range` <chr>, …

1. Clean excerpts with clean_data()

The clean_data() function standardizes column names, keeps the highest ranked coder per transcript, drops range/weight columns, prefixes code variables with c_, and returns both the cleaned data and a codebook. Supply the mock data along with your preferred coder order. You can optionally rename and relabel variables at the same time.

preferred_coders <- c("Aliyah", "Rohan")

cleaned <- clean_data(
  excerpts = demo_excerpts,
  preferred_coders = preferred_coders,
  rename_vars = list(resource_author = "resource_creator"),
  relabel_vars = list(
    media_title = "Interview or focus group title",
    resource_author = "Team member who uploaded to Dedoose"
  )
)

cleaned$data
#> # A tibble: 3 × 11
#>   media_title excerpt_creator excerpt_date excerpt resource_author resource_date
#>   <chr>       <chr>           <date>       <chr>   <chr>           <date>       
#> 1 Interview:… Aliyah          2023-04-12   I fina… Staff Team      2023-04-01   
#> 2 Focus Grou… Rohan           2023-07-28   Staff … Evaluation Lead 2023-07-15   
#> 3 Interview:… Aliyah          2024-01-08   That m… Alumni Coordin… 2023-12-20   
#> # ℹ 5 more variables: codes_applied_combined <chr>,
#> #   c_sense_of_belonging_connectedness <lgl>,
#> #   c_sense_of_belonging_connectedness_peers <lgl>, c_long_term_impact <lgl>,
#> #   coder_rank <int>

Reviewing the codebook that ships with the cleaned data helps confirm variable labels and types before moving on.

#> media_title                                                           media_title

#> resource_date                                                       resource_date

#> c_sense_of_belonging_connectedness             c_sense_of_belonging_connectedness
#> c_sense_of_belonging_connectedness_peers c_sense_of_belonging_connectedness_peers
#> c_long_term_impact                                             c_long_term_impact

#>                                                                                        label

#> excerpt_creator                                                coder who created the excerpt
#> excerpt_date                                                        date excerpt was created
#> excerpt                                                                 full text of excerpt
#> resource_author                                          Team member who uploaded to Dedoose
#> resource_date                                     date media/transcript was added to Dedoose

#> c_sense_of_belonging_connectedness_peers   logical
#> c_long_term_impact                         logical
#> coder_rank                                 integer

2. Merge related codes with merge_codes()

When multiple codes capture the same idea, merge_codes() combines them into a single logical column and updates the codebook. Here, the general belonging code and its peers sub-code are collapsed into one composite while the remaining codes stay as-is.

merged <- merge_codes(
  data = cleaned$data,
  merges = list(
    c_belonging_connectedness = c(
      "c_sense_of_belonging_connectedness",
      "c_sense_of_belonging_connectedness_peers"
    )
  ),
  relabel_vars = list(
    c_belonging_connectedness = "Belonging or connectedness mentioned"
  )
)

merged$data_merged
#> # A tibble: 3 × 10
#>   media_title excerpt_creator excerpt_date excerpt resource_author resource_date
#>   <chr>       <chr>           <date>       <chr>   <chr>           <date>       
#> 1 Interview:… Aliyah          2023-04-12   I fina… Staff Team      2023-04-01   
#> 2 Focus Grou… Rohan           2023-07-28   Staff … Evaluation Lead 2023-07-15   
#> 3 Interview:… Aliyah          2024-01-08   That m… Alumni Coordin… 2023-12-20   
#> # ℹ 4 more variables: codes_applied_combined <chr>, c_long_term_impact <lgl>,
#> #   coder_rank <int>, c_belonging_connectedness <lgl>
merged$codebook_merged
#>                                            variable
#> media_title                             media_title
#> excerpt_creator                     excerpt_creator
#> excerpt_date                           excerpt_date
#> excerpt                                     excerpt
#> resource_author                     resource_author
#> resource_date                         resource_date
#> codes_applied_combined       codes_applied_combined
#> c_long_term_impact               c_long_term_impact

#> c_belonging_connectedness c_belonging_connectedness
#>                                                                         label
#> media_title                                    Interview or focus group title
#> excerpt_creator                                 coder who created the excerpt
#> excerpt_date                                         date excerpt was created
#> excerpt                                                  full text of excerpt
#> resource_author                           Team member who uploaded to Dedoose
#> resource_date                      date media/transcript was added to Dedoose
#> codes_applied_combined                           all codes applied to excerpt
#> c_long_term_impact                                           long-term impact
#> coder_rank                rank of coder, according to listed coder preference
#> c_belonging_connectedness                Belonging or connectedness mentioned
#>                                type

#> excerpt_creator           character
#> excerpt_date                   Date
#> excerpt                   character

#> resource_date                  Date
#> codes_applied_combined    character
#> c_long_term_impact          logical
#> coder_rank                  integer
#> c_belonging_connectedness   logical

3. Explore excerpts with view_excerpts()

Finally, surface the excerpts behind each code. view_excerpts() opens an interactive table powered by DT, letting you filter by code and search within text. To keep vignette builds stable, the chunk only runs when DT is available.

if (requireNamespace("DT", quietly = TRUE)) {
  view_excerpts(merged$data_merged)
} else {
  message("Install the DT package to launch the interactive excerpt browser.")
}

Replace demo_excerpts with your actual export when it is ready—the workflow remains the same. Start with clean_data() to standardize everything, merge or retire codes as your analysis evolves, and lean on view_excerpts() whenever you want to reconnect with the qualitative stories behind the summaries.
